across.text: Ancient musical instrument, not exactly novel
across.explanation: REBECCA(i.e. “novel” by Daphne Du Maurier). Solution is REBEC (i.e. “ancient musical instrument” akin to a mandolin, apparently) followed by CA (i.e. “not exactly”, i.e. a recognised abbreviation of “circa”).

across.text: Show loyal friendship, perhaps, with press chief in retreat
across.explanation: BACK-PEDAL(i.e. “retreat”). Solution is BACK PAL (i.e. “show loyal friendship”) wrapped around or having “in” ED (i.e. “press chief”, short for an editor), like so: BACK-P(ED)AL.

across.text: Hit recalled for granny?
across.explanation: KNOT(i.e. “granny”, a variant thereof). Solution is TONK (i.e. “hit”) reversed (indicated by “recalled”).

across.text: As we were on a quest astute, largely, to be organised
across.explanation: STATUS QUO ANTE(i.e. “as we were” in Latin, because, you know, The Times…) Solution is an anagram of ON A QUEST and ASTUTE once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “largely”).

across.text: Film makers did show with some Japanese cooking
across.explanation: CAMERAMEN(i.e. “film makers”). Solution is CAME (i.e. “did show” or appear) followed by RAMEN (i.e. “Japanese cooking”).

across.text: Force unit to broadcast each November in style of French author
across.explanation: VOLTAIREAN(i.e. “in style of French author”, specifically ‘im wot didCandide). Solution is VOLT (i.e. “force unit”) followed by AIR (i.e. “to broadcast”), then EA (a recognised abbreviation of “each”) and N (“November” in the phonetic alphabet).

across.text: Stop early, returning home: beer with male friend
across.explanation: NIP IN THE BUD(i.e. “stop early”). Solution is IN (i.e. “home”) reversed (indicated by “returning”) and followed by PINT (i.e. “beer”), then HE (i.e. “male”) and BUD (i.e. “friend”), like so: NI-PINT-HE-BUD.

across.text: One having shot rook involved in row
across.explanation: TRIER(i.e. “one having shot” or a go at something). Solution is R (a recognised abbreviation of “rook” used in chess) placed or “involved in” TIER (i.e. “row”), like so: T(R)IER.

across.text: Free issue including photo that’s been withdrawn
across.explanation: EMANCIPATE(i.e. to “free”). Solution is EMANATE (i.e. “issue”) wrapped around or “including” PIC (i.e. “photo”) once reversed (indicated by “that’s been withdrawn”), like so: EMAN(CIP)ATE.

across.text: Set sights on corporate tax IFC’s holding over
across.explanation: FIXATE(i.e. “set sights on”). “Holding” indicates the solution has been hidden in the clue, while “over” indicates the solution has been reversed, like so: CORPORAT(E TAX IF)C’S.

across.text: Girl who came out on maybe weekly drive, bypassing E German town
across.explanation: MAGDEBERG(i.e. “German town”, in which the effects of atmospheric pressure was proven by holding two hemispheres together and pumping the air out from between them. Yes, of course I looked it up). Solution is DEB (i.e. “girl who came out”, short for debutante) placed “on” of after MAG (i.e. “maybe weekly” publication, short for magazine) and followed by URGE (i.e. “drive”) once the E has been removed (indicated by “bypassing E”), like so: MAG-(DEB)-URG.

across.text: Reading matter keeping I see within the law
across.explanation: LICIT(i.e. “within the law”). Solution is LIT (i.e. “reading matter”, short for literature) wrapped around or “keeping” I and C (“see”, one of its variant meanings is the spoken form of the letter ‘C’), like so: L(I-C)IT.

across.text: Graduate playing clumsily with a small set of keys
across.explanation: BAHAMAS(i.e. “set of keys” or islands). Solution is BA (i.e. “graduate”, specifically a Bachelor of Arts) followed by HAM (i.e. acting or “playing clumsily”), then A and S (a recognised abbreviation of “small”).

across.text: Bloomers in letter by Pentagon – demise of Reagan?
across.explanation: RHODODENDRONS(i.e. “bloomers”). Solution is RHO (i.e. “letter”, specifically the seventeenth letter of the Greek alphabet) followed by DOD (i.e. “Pentagon”, in this case the Department Of Defence), then END (i.e. “demise”) and RON’S (i.e. “of Reagan”, referencing a shortened form of the former US president’s first name).

across.text: Order to be collected from elderly butcher serving part-time
across.explanation: DON’T PANIC. Solution satisfies “order to be collected” or keep calm, and “elderly butcher serving part-time”, a reference to the catchphrase of Clive Dunn’s character Lance Corporal Jones in the BBC sitcomDad’s Army[…, a butcher by trade. – edit courtesy of Sue in the comments. Cheers, Sue! – LP.]

across.text: Learner celebrated mathematician clinching City University teaching job
across.explanation: LECTURING(i.e. “university teaching job”). Solution is L (a recognised abbreviation of “learner”) and Alan TURING (i.e. “celebrated mathematician”) all wrapped around or “clinching” EC (i.e. “City”, basically the City of London’s postcode area. The Times is a London newspaper, so…), like so: L-(EC)-TURING.

across.text: Photo op formed originally for Cassandra
across.explanation: PROPHET OF DOOM(i.e. “Cassandra”, who in Greek myth was doomed to foresee events and not be believed). “Originally” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of PHOTO OP FORMED.

across.text: Writer Romeo, back in the day, one for Flower Power generation
across.explanation: TURBINE(i.e. “one for Flower Power generation” – ignore the misleading capitalisation, the setter is playing on flowers being rivers, as in how they flow. Turbines, meanwhile, are used to generate hydroelectric power). Solution is NIB (i.e. “writer”) and R (“Romeo” in the phonetic alphabet) both reversed (indicated by “back”) and placed “in” TUE (i.e. “day”, in this case short for Tuesday), like so: TU(R-BIN)E.

across.text: In place of classic poems, novel
across.explanation: EPSOM(i.e. “in place of classic”, a reference to the horse race that takes place there). “Novel” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of POEMS.

across.text: Love having one’s fair share of trouble?
across.explanation: ADORATION(i.e. “love”). When written as ADO RATION the solution also playfully satisfies “having one’s fair share of trouble”.

across.text: Strong material, when front has split, weakening
across.explanation: EBBING(i.e. “weakening”). Solution is WEBBING (i.e. “strong material”) with the first letter removed (indicated by “when front has split”).

across.text: Frame of picture, or highly ornate ancient symbol
across.explanation: HIEROGLYPH(i.e. “ancient symbol”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “ornate”) of PE (i.e. “frame of picture”, i.e. the first and last letters of “picture”) and OR HIGHLY.

across.text: Floor cover
across.explanation: THROW. Solution satisfies to “floor” or surprise someone, and a “cover” e.g. for a sofa.

across.text: Earth for example from plot and from abroad needed by Tom or Barbara?
across.explanation: MAJOR PLANET(i.e. “Earth for example”). Solution is PLAN (i.e. “plot”) and ET (i.e. “and from abroad”, i.e. the French for “and”) placed after MAJOR (i.e. “Tom or Barbara” – the former a reference to Major Tom, a recurring character in some David Bowie songs; the latter a reference toMajor Barbara, a play by George Bernard Shaw), like so: MAJOR-(PLAN-ET).

across.text: Stoker needing hot drink not saying thanks?
across.explanation: CHAIN GRATE(i.e. “stoker” – over to Chambers: “a device for stoking a furnace in which fuel is drawn into the furnace by means of a rotating chain”. I’m still none the wiser). Solution is CHA (i.e. “hot drink” or an informal word for tea) followed by INGRATE (i.e. “not saying thanks”).

across.text: Outlaw’s especially long time inside not even with remission?
across.explanation: DESPERADO(i.e. “outlaw”). Solution is ESP (a recognised abbreviation of “especially” often used in dictionaries) and ERA (i.e. “long time”) both placed “inside” of ODD (i.e. “not even”) once reversed (indicated by “with remission”), like so: D(ESP-ERA)DO.

across.text: Request for news that’s unexpected!
across.explanation: WHAT DO YOU KNOW. Solution satisfies “request for news” and an exclamatory expression meaning “that’s unexpected”.

across.text: 1 down to choose university for a career
across.explanation: RUSH(i.e. “career”). The solution to “1 down” is RASH. Here we’re swapping A “for” U (a recognised abbreviation of “university”), like so: R(A)SH => R(U)SH.

across.text: Popular English composer died: that’s a shock!
across.explanation: I NEVER DID(i.e. “that’s a shock”). Solution is IN (i.e. “popular”) followed by E (a recognised abbreviation of “English”), then Giuseppe VERDI (i.e. “composer”) and D (a recognised abbreviation of “died”).

across.text: Unemotional, but on consuming whiskey, reddened?
across.explanation: DRY-EYED(i.e. “unemotional”). Solution is DYED (i.e. “reddened”) wrapped around or “consuming” RYE (i.e. “whiskey”), like so: D(RYE)YED.

down.text: Not considered an unwelcome series
down.explanation: RASH. Solution satisfies “not considered” and “an unwelcome series”, presumably of spots.

down.text: Heavily publicising law graduate with answer on regionalisation
down.explanation: BLAZONING(i.e. “heavily publicising”). Solution is BL (i.e. “law graduate”, specifically a Bachelor of Law) followed by A (a recognised abbreviation of “answer”, as in Q&A) then ZONING (i.e. “regionalisation”).

down.text: Bar turn by stars – not rising ones?
down.explanation: COUNTER-REVOLUTIONARIES(i.e. “not rising ones”). Solution is COUNTER (i.e. “bar”) followed by REVOLUTION (i.e. “turn”) and ARIES (i.e. a constellation of “stars”).

down.text: Come by with a lot of paper for the auditors
down.explanation: ACQUIRE(i.e. “come by”). Solution is A followed by a homophone (indicated by “for the auditors”) of QUIRE (i.e. “lot of paper”).

down.text: Returned unexpectedly, as did thunder across mountains
down.explanation: BOOMERANGED(i.e. “returned unexpectedly”). Solution is BOOMED (i.e. “did thunder”) wrapped around or placed “across” RANGE (i.e. “mountains”), like so: BOOME(RANGE)D.

down.text: Accepted article for wearing like a dunce’s hat?
down.explanation: CANONICAL(i.e. “accepted”). Solution is AN (i.e. “article”, i.e. a word like a, an or the) placed in or “wearing” CONICAL (i.e. “like a dunce’s hat”), like so: C(AN)ONICAL.

down.text: Hymn from non-believer having change of heart
down.explanation: PAEAN(i.e. “hymn”). Solution is PAGAN (i.e. “non-believer”) with the middle letter changed to E (indicated by “having change of heart” – I’m seldom keen on wishy-washy wordplay like this), like so: PA(G)AN => PA(E)AN.

down.text: Poorly paid cadet, note, not having a bean?
down.explanation: DECAPITATED(i.e. “not having a bean” – a variant meaning of “bean” is an informal word for one’s head). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “poorly”) of PAID CADET and TE (i.e. “note” in the sol-fa notation, or doh-ray-me). Another thing I’m not keen on is when setters perform a double-jump in their clues, in this case expecting solvers to unscramble an anagram that isn’t possible without first also deducing what “note” refers to.

down.text: Tart left money splashed out
down.explanation: LEMONY(i.e. “tart” or sharp-tasting). Solution is L (a recognised abbreviation of “left”) followed by an anagram (indicated by “splashed out” – again, scruffy. “Splashed” as an anagram indicator? That’s fine. “Out”? Yup, that’s okay as well. “Splashed out” though? Really?) of MONEY, like so: L-EMONY.

down.text: Staff turning up one short prejudice foreign state
down.explanation: NAMIBIA(i.e. “foreign state”). Solution is MAN (i.e. to “staff” an organisation) reversed (indicated by “turning up” – this being a down clue) and followed by I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”), then BIAS (i.e. “prejudice”) once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “short”), like so: NAM-I-BIA.

down.text: Garment is big top put on by female medic?
down.explanation: TENT DRESS(i.e. “garment”). I think the clue is playing on a circus TENT being a “big top” and a DR-ESS being a “female medic”, i.e. a recognised abbreviation of “doctor” with a “-ESS” suffix.

down.text: Abbey church prior on fast unsettled leading cleric
down.explanation: ARCHBISHOP OF CANTERBURY(i.e. “leading cleric”). “Unsettled” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of ABBEY CHURCH PRIOR ON FAST. Nicely worked.

down.text: Cart with breadbasket falling on Belgian singer
down.explanation: TUMBREL(i.e. a ye olde “cart” used to carry dung, and also those condemned to hang. Lovely!) Solution is TUM (i.e. “breadbasket” or belly) followed by Jacques BREL (i.e. “Belgian singer” – no, me neither).

down.text: Artist’s abnormal craving’s like this
down.explanation: PabloPICASSO(i.e. “artist”). Solution is PICA’S (i.e. “abnormal craving” for food – a new one on me – made possessive) followed by SO (i.e. “like this”).

down.text: A tip for rubbish? One with nothing from the start
down.explanation: AB INITIO(i.e. “from the start” in Latin). Solution is A followed by BIN IT (i.e. a hint or “tip for rubbish”), then I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”) and O (i.e. “nothing”). One nailed from the wordplay, unsurprisingly.

down.text: As written or spoken French, filling university requirement
down.explanation: UNEDITED(i.e. “as written”). Solution is DIT (i.e. “spoken French”, i.e. the French for “said”) placed in or “filling” U (a recognised abbreviation of “university”) and NEED (i.e. “requirement”), like so: U-NE(DIT)ED. Bloody hell, if there was ever a clue that deserved the French meme it’s this, so…

down.text: Writer’s scaled down poem, unromantically
down.explanation: JamesMUNRO(i.e. “writer”, a pseudonym used by author and TV writer James Mitchell, creator of the 1970s TV seriesWhen The Boat Comes InandCallan, and through which he published four novels in the 1960s. Except, of course, it isn’t him at all. One of the unwritten rules of Times crosswords is that people have to be dead to feature in them, and I’ll bet good money the setter had the much better-known Alice Munro in mind when writing this clue. Trouble is she is still alive… unless of course the setter knows something we don’t. Hmm. Book ’em, Danno…) “Scaled down” indicates the solution has been hidden in the clue, like so: POE(M UNRO)MANTICALLY.

down.text: Come to mind old dog that’s caught cold
down.explanation: OCCUR(i.e. “come to mind”). Solution is O (a recognised abbreviation of “old”) and CUR (i.e. “dog”) wrapped around or “catching” C (a recognised abbreviation of “cold” used on taps), like so: O-(C)-CUR.

down.text: One to contend with pensioner missing a sitter
down.explanation: OPPOSER(i.e. “one to contend with”). Solution is OAP (i.e. short for old age “pensioner”) with the A removed (indicated by “missing a”) and the remainder followed by POSER (i.e. “sitter” or artist’s model), like so: OP-POSER.

down.text: Urgent invitation, perhaps, bringing mild reproof
down.explanation: COME NOW. Solution satisfies “urgent invitation” and “mild reproof”.

down.text: Recognise an unusual feature
down.explanation: GRECIAN NOSE(i.e. “feature”). “Unusual” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of RECOGNISE AN.

down.text: Unsubtle fellow poet’s indeed offered gripping verse
down.explanation: HEAVY-HANDED(i.e. “unsubtle”). Solution is HE (i.e. “fellow”), AY (i.e. “poet’s indeed”, a poetic form of yes or always) and HANDED (i.e. “offered”) all wrapped around or “gripping” V (a recognised abbreviation of “verse”), like so: HE-A(V)Y-HANDED.

down.text: Jollies I had with other ranks once a month
down.explanation: THERMIDOR(i.e. “once a month” – over to Chambers again: “the eleventh month of the French Revolutionary calendar, 19 July – 17th August”). Solution is THE RM (i.e. “jollies” – one definition of “jolly” is a slang word for a Royal Marine; meanwhile RM is a recognised abbreviation of the Royal Marines) followed by I’D (a contraction of “I had”) and OR (a recognised abbreviation of the “Other Ranks” of the British Army).

down.text: Staff flourished for a spell
down.explanation: MAGIC WAND. Clue plays on a wand being a “staff”, and how magic wands are wafted around when casting a “spell”. You get the idea.

down.text: Irish girl being educated in New York caught bug?
down.explanation: IRRITANCY(i.e. “bug”). Solution is IR (a recognised abbreviation of “Irish”) followed by RITA (i.e. “girl being educated”, referencing Willy Russell’s stage playEducating Rita) and NY (short for “New York”) once wrapped around or having “in” C (a recognised abbreviation of “caught” used in a number of ball games), like so: IR-RITA-N(C)Y.

down.text: My bride after vacation in France I suspect
down.explanation: BEJESUS(i.e. “my”, both exclamations of surprise – backed up by my Oxford. Weirdly my Chambers doesn’t want to know). Solution is BE (i.e. “bride after vacation”, i.e. the word “bride” with all of its middle letters removed) followed by JE (i.e. “in France I”, i.e. the French for “I”) and SUS (slang form of “suspect”).

down.text: Tune you had that’s soothing
down.explanation: HONEYED(i.e. “soothing”). Solution is HONE (i.e. to “tune”) followed by YE’D (I think a contraction of “you had”, taking YE to be “you” – again, I’m not keen).

down.text: Lime maybe drunk mostly without a hint of lemon
down.explanation: ALKALI(i.e. “lime maybe”). Solution is ALKIE (i.e. “drunk”, slang for alcoholic) with the last letter removed (indicated by “mostly”) and the remainder wrapped around or placed “without” A and L (i.e. “hint of lemon”, i.e. the first letter of “lemon”), like so: ALK(A-L)I.

down.text: Strap we see on odd occasions no more?
down.explanation: TAWSE(i.e. a leather “strap” used for corporal punishment). “On odd occasions no more” indicates the solution is derived by taking the odd letters away from STRAPWESEE.

down.text: A day filled with dread
down.explanation: AWED(i.e. “filled with dread”). Solution is A followed by WED (i.e. “day”, short for Wednesday).
